item.title: Remote connecting to my VMware homelab - ZeroTier
item.description:
I recently decided to move my homelab from my appartment to the building's basement for noise and space purposes. I wanted to access my lab by buidling a simple VPN connection between my home internet router and a 4G router that I installed.

Problem : Most of the 4G providers in Switzerland do not provide a public IPv4 but a nated address in their own space. Unless you find a port mapping, you won't be able to build your VPN connection.

I could have used Teamviewer or any other solutions in the market but I really wanted to access my vCenter like I would do if I would have built a VPN.

Introducing ZeroTier

ZeroTier one is a "free" software agent that creates secure networks between devices whether these devices are on-premise, cloud, desktop or mobile devices.

How does it work?

The first step is to create a network in their online portal. This will allow you to connect multiple devices the newly created network. The network will contain an ID that you need to keep as you will need to specify it when you will be connecting different devices.

Once the network is created, you can select a range that will be used to provide IP addresses to the agents installed. Obviously, do not select a range that will overlap your current range.In my case, I selected the range 10.144.x.x/16.

The network has been setup. Now, you need to install the agent within the device you want to connect. Specify the network to join (the network ID created before) and authorize the device within the online portal. That's it. Devices can now communicate between each other within the ZeroTier network range.

How do you access machines without the agent ?

Now that we've seen how to connect devices to the ZeroTierOne network, we will see a method to do not have to install an agent on all devices. As an example for my homelab, I want to be able to access my vCenter or every other ESXis without installing an agent on it. Basically, we will route the Zerotier network to our physical network.

This becomes possible by using a raspberry pi, or another machine (in my case I choose to use a virtual machine) as long as you have iptables. It will use a NAT/Masquerading method.

My homelab is built as per the diagram below. The objectives here are to be able to reach the management VLAN 192.168.2.x network located in my basement from my home LAN which is 192.168.1.0/24.

First, we install Zerotier on the VM and join your network:

1curl -s https://install.zerotier.com | sudo bash
2sudo zerotier-cli join abcdefghi73

Obviously I indicated a fake network id (abcdefghi73) do not forget to correct it.

Then, we will identify the interfaces used :

1ip link

As we can see here, ens160 is my virtual machine virtual interface and ztyouyu7qc is the zero tier virtual interface. Let's now find out our IP addresses :

1ip a

We can see that my IP address is 192.168.100.160/24 in my private LAN and 10.144.49.76/16 in the ZeroTier Network.

It is time now to add the route within the Tier Zero portal as we identified the IP addresses :

In the routes above, you will notice that I did not use a /24 for my internal lab. Following the documentation of Zerotier, they advise the following :

Configure the destination route as slightly larger than the actual physical subnet, here /23 instead of /24 (a smaller number is a bigger subnet in this notation) This makes devices that are on both the physical and the ZeroTier network prefer the physical connection.

Now, let's define some variables for future commands:

1PHY_IFACE=ens160; ZT_IFACE=ztyouyu7qc;

The next step is to enable IP Forwarding. We need to enable it now and make sure it persists between reboot (I am running Ubuntu).

1sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.ip_forward=1

Uncomment net.ipv4.ip_forward by removing the # before the line.

1sudo vi /etc/sysctl.conf

The device is now capable to forward packets between the physical (virtual in my case) interface and the virtual Zero tier interface.

To conclude, we will now configure authorize these packets to go from one to another with iptables :

1sudo iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o $PHY_IFACE -j MASQUERADE
2sudo iptables -A FORWARD -i $PHY_IFACE -o $ZT_IFACE -m state --state RELATED,ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT
3sudo iptables -A FORWARD -i $ZT_IFACE -o $PHY_IFACE -j ACCEPT

In order to have these rules persistent across reboots :

1sudo apt install iptables-persistent
2sudo bash -c iptables-save > /etc/iptables/rules.v4

That's it! You should now be able to ping your internal IP addresses!

I really like this software and it helped me a lot. I will now replace my virtual machine by a Raspberry pi in the next few weeks.

Kudos to J.Wilk for sharing this with me!
